intro: Tetrapterys tysonii, commonly known as the Tyson's false hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant features showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically pink or red in color. Its leaves are palmately lobed, with five to seven lobes, giving it a distinctive appearance. Tetrapterys tysonii is often found in coastal areas and thrives in sandy or limestone soils.
